results.title: The Bat whispers [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roland West and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: An arch-criminal known as ‘The Bat’ who taunts police officers by providing clues about his upcoming crimes, terrorises the occupants of an isolated mansion during a raging thunderstorm. Though highly formulaic with all the narrative and iconographic cliches of the melodramatic haunted house genre such as rooms concealed behind swiveling fireplaces, subplots revolving around fragments of obscure treasure maps, shots, screams and faulty electric lighting, the film distinguishes itself through a succession of astonishing visual sequences. Director Roland West specially designed and constructed equipment and models that allowed the camera to exuberantly swoop, glide and zoom through space, hurtle down corridors and lurch from the tops of buildings. The stylised high-contrast expressionistic lighting is evocative of the German silent cinema which the director revered. One of the first films to be shot in widescreen (65mm ‘Magnifilm’), this version has been restored by the UCLA film archive. Nine years after the film’s release, the memory of its caped master-criminal inspired young comic-book artist Bob Kane to create a new superhero: Batman.

results.title: Martin Scorsese directs
results.creator_credit: Steven Fischer, Joel Sucher and Pacific Street Film Projects
results.brief_description: This documentary visits the set, the editing rooms and the mixing studios during the production of “Goodfellas”. It also includes many clips from his body of work including “Mean Streets”, “Raging Bull”, “New York, New York” and “The Last Temptation of Christ”, as well as interviews with the director, his family, friends and colleagues from the film world such as Steven Spielberg, Robert De Niro, Harvey Keitel, Joe Pesci, and George Lucas.

results.title: Tales of the Taira Clan = Shin heiki monogatari
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Masaichi Nagata and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: Set in twelfth-century Japan against a rich social and political background, this is an epic tale of power struggles, family drama, and human frailty. Mizoguchi lavished everything - sumptuous colour, elaborate sets and costumes - on this gripping drama, making his penultimate film - only one of two films he made in colour - a masterpiece. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Ordet = The Word
results.creator_credit: Carl Theodor Dreyer and Palladium Films
results.brief_description: Ordet = (The Word) is film that explores the polarities of faith and the journey from hypocrisy to true faith. In a remote village in Denmark, two families feud as a result of opposing religious faiths and their religious intolerance. Old Borgen’s family is further tested when his son, Johannes is driven mad by reading Kierkegarde and believes he is the risen Christ. Dreyer simply explores the notion of faith by illustrating the inadequacies of doctrines when pitted against people with profound needs. True faith is explored when the family turn in desperation to each other as Inger, the wife of Borgen’s older son Mikkel and light of the family unexpectedly dies. Dreyer reduces the sound in the film in a way that creates a meditative atmosphere heightening its religious theme. In Danish with English subtitles.

results.title: Clubbed to death
results.creator_credit: Yolande Zauberman, Alain Massiot and Madar
results.brief_description: Set in the outskirts of Paris, “Clubbed to death” offers a fresh perspective of the rave culture by setting it’s story amongst the Arab and African immigrant community that populate these poorer suburbs and vibrant dance scene. Elodie Bouchez (‘Dream life of angels’(1998), ‘Wild reeds’ (1994)) plays Lola, a 20 year-old club kid who falls asleep on the bus home one night and wakes to find herself in the middle of a popular night spot where local Arab and African teenagers go to party. On this eventful evening Lola pops an E and meets and falls in love with a boxer called Emir (Roschdy Zem). Like Alice in wonderland finding herself on the other side of the rabbit hole, the drugged out Lola must overcome various obstacles and opponents before she can be with her man. Her biggest hurdle’s are Emir’s vampy girlfriend and club podium dancer Saida (Beatrice Dalle), whose love for him borders on the obsessive, and Emir’s own struggle with heroin addiction. Director Yolande Zauberman chooses to treat this twilight world in a naturalistic, unflashy way through the use of hand held camera but heightens the visuals and narrative through the impressive electronic soundtrack which includes dance artists such as Massive Attack, Daft Punk and the Chemical Brothers. In French with English subtitles. Cast also includes Richard Courchet, Gerald Thomassin and Julie Bataille.

results.title: Sweet sweetback's baadasssss song (E)
results.brief_description: Starring the Black Community and directed, scripted, edited and produced by Melvin Van Peebles, “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song” is one of the most influential of American underground/independent films. Influenced by the radical turn in the civil rights movement, and the resulting rise of the Black Panthers, “Sweet Sweetback …” makes no apologies for its revolutionary ardour. The police in this film are racist and corrupt, white people are murderous and the black population of the United States are still economic and cultural “slaves” to the “Man”. The film’s controversial and subversive power comes from suggesting that the very criminality and sexual licentiousness that racists have associated with the “African”, may be the very qualities the black population can use against their oppressors. Sweetback is a hustler, raised in a brothel. Picked up by the police one night, he snaps when the police begin brutalising a young revolutionary. For the rest of the film, Sweetback is running; running away from a racist America that will not tolerate an “uppity nigger”. Sly, fast and often cruelly funny, the film was made on a miniscule budget and is now unmistakably a result of the counter-cultural ferment of the late sixties. Van Peebles’s work is a pioneering work of Afro-American cinema, and though often considered a precursor to blaxploitation, it is a defiantly angry and passionate work. Features an acid funk music score by Earth, Wind and Fire. The video includes the movie’s original trailer as well as an interview with Van Peebles filmed in the late nineties.

results.title: Nil by mouth [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Gary Oldman, Douglas Urbanski, Luc Besson, SE8 and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This is a raw, unflinching look at a dysfunctional family as it copes with alcoholism, drug abuse, petty crime and domestic violence in South East London. Gary Oldman’s brilliantly written screen-play and stunning direction perfectly capture the solidarity, resilience and humour that make survival possible.

results.title: The Mother and the whore = La Maman et la putan
results.creator_credit: Jean Eustache, Pierre Cottrell, V.M. Productions, Simar Films, Les Films du Losange, Cine Qua Non and Elite Films
results.brief_description: Jean-Pierre Leaud is a young intellectual who has relationships with two very different women, the faithful Marie and the promiscuous Veronika. “The Mother and the Whore” is an exploration of contemporary sexual relationships which concentrates on the bohemian subcultures of the disillusioned left. Dialogue, argument and dialect are what this film focuses upon, allowing for a candid and radical re-examination of the meaning of commitment and desire, as well as examining the often cataclysmic effects of feminism on gender roles and expectations. Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival, “The Mother and the Whore” remains one of the most important and most admired of “Nouvelle Vague” cinema. The irony being, of course, is that in its detached over-view of the games between men and women, and in it’s ruthless mocking of the insularity of the French intelligentsia, the film initiates a clear break with the passionate and romantic idealism of the sixties new wave.

results.title: The Crossing guard
results.creator_credit: Sean Penn, David Shamroy Hamburger and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Melancholy tale about a father who falls into alcoholism after his daughter is killed in a drink-driving accident. Estranged from his wife and fuelled by vengeance, Freddy awaits the release of the killer from jail, giving him three days to live. Stellar performances from Jack Nicholson and Anjelica Houston underpin this searing morality drama that tackles grief, guilt, and redemption. Also stars Robin Wright Penn and Piper Laurie.

results.title: The World according to Garp
results.creator_credit: George Roy Hill, Robert L. Crawford and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This film version of John Irving’s novel “The World According to Garp” brilliantly captures the quirky spirit of the original story. T.S. Garp is the illegitimate child of unorthodox feminist Jenny Fields. Every effort made by Jenny to broaden Garp’s outlook on life crams more fears and phobias into his psyche. Aspiring to become a novelist, Garp succeeds in this goal at the same time that his mother achieves fame through the publishing of her first feminist manifesto. Though successful and happily married to his college sweetheart, Garp remains envious of his fearless mother. Cast includes: Robin Williams, Mary Beth Hurt, Glenn Close and John Lithgow.
